title: Introduction to Python
description: Welcome to Python programming! Learn what Python is and why it's popular.

steps.title: What is Python?
steps.content: Python is a high-level, interpreted programming language created by Guido van Rossum in 1991. It's designed with readability in mind, using English keywords and simple syntax. Python is used in web development, data science, artificial intelligence, automation, and scientific computing.

steps.title: Why Choose Python?
steps.content:
• Easy to learn and read - Python's syntax is clean and intuitive
• Versatile - Used in many fields from web apps to AI
• Large community - Millions of developers worldwide
• Rich libraries - Thousands of pre-built packages available
• Cross-platform - Runs on Windows, Mac, Linux

steps.title: Your First Python Program
steps.content: The traditional first program in any language prints 'Hello, World!' to the screen:
steps.code:
print('Hello, World!')
print('Welcome to Python programming!')
print('Python is', 2024 - 1991, 'years old')

practiceProblems.title: Personal Greeting
practiceProblems.description: Create a program that prints a greeting with your name.
practiceProblems.starterCode: # Print a greeting with your name
practiceProblems.expectedOutput: Hello, my name is [Your Name]
practiceProblems.solution: print('Hello, my name is Alice')

practiceProblems.title: Python Facts
practiceProblems.description: Print three interesting facts about Python using multiple print statements.
practiceProblems.starterCode: # Print three facts about Python
practiceProblems.expectedOutput:
Fact 1: Python was named after Monty Python
Fact 2: Python is open source
Fact 3: Python is interpreted, not compiled
practiceProblems.solution:
print('Fact 1: Python was named after Monty Python')
print('Fact 2: Python is open source')
print('Fact 3: Python is interpreted, not compiled')

practiceProblems.title: Dynamic Information
practiceProblems.description: Create a program that displays the current year and calculates Python's age dynamically.
practiceProblems.starterCode:
# Calculate and display Python's age
# Python was created in 1991
practiceProblems.expectedOutput:
Current year: 2024
Python's age: 33 years
practiceProblems.solution:
import datetime
current_year = datetime.datetime.now().year
python_birth_year = 1991
age = current_year - python_birth_year
print(f'Current year: {current_year}')
print(f'Python\'s age: {age} years')

quiz.question: Who created the Python programming language?
Python was first released in which year?
Which function is used to display output in Python?

title: Variables and Data Types
description: Learn to store and manipulate different types of data in Python.

steps.title: Understanding Variables
steps.content: A variable is a named storage location in memory that holds data. In Python, variables are created when you assign a value to them. Unlike other languages, you don't need to declare the variable type - Python automatically determines it based on the value assigned.

steps.title: Creating Variables
steps.content: Here's how to create variables of different types:
steps.code:
# String variable
name = 'Alice'
full_name = "Alice Johnson"

# Integer variable
age = 25
year = 2024

# Float variable
height = 5.6
temperature = 98.6

# Boolean variable
is_student = True
has_job = False

print(name, age, height, is_student)

steps.title: Python Data Types
steps.content:
Python has several built-in data types:

• str (String) - Text data: 'Hello'
• int (Integer) - Whole numbers: 42
• float - Decimal numbers: 3.14
• bool (Boolean) - True or False
• list - Ordered collection: [1, 2, 3]
• dict (Dictionary) - Key-value pairs: {'key': 'value'}
• tuple - Immutable sequence: (1, 2, 3)
• set - Unique elements: {1, 2, 3}

steps.title: Checking Data Types
steps.content: Use the type() function to check what type of data a variable contains:
steps.code:
name = 'Alice'
age = 25
height = 5.6
is_student = True

print(type(name))      # <class 'str'>
print(type(age))       # <class 'int'>
print(type(height))    # <class 'float'>
print(type(is_student)) # <class 'bool'>

practiceProblems.title: Personal Information
practiceProblems.description: Create variables to store your name, age, and favorite color, then print them.
practiceProblems.starterCode: # Create variables for personal information
practiceProblems.expectedOutput:
Name: Alice
Age: 25
Favorite Color: Blue
practiceProblems.solution:
name = 'Alice'
age = 25
favorite_color = 'Blue'

print('Name:', name)
print('Age:', age)
print('Favorite Color:', favorite_color)

practiceProblems.title: Variable Operations
practiceProblems.description: Create numeric variables and perform basic calculations, storing results in new variables.
practiceProblems.starterCode:
# Create variables for a rectangle's dimensions
length = 10
width = 5
# Calculate area and perimeter
practiceProblems.expectedOutput:
Area: 50
Perimeter: 30
practiceProblems.solution:
length = 10
width = 5
area = length * width
perimeter = 2 * (length + width)

print('Area:', area)
print('Perimeter:', perimeter)

practiceProblems.title: Type Conversion Challenge
practiceProblems.description: Create a program that takes string numbers, converts them to integers, performs calculations, and displays results.
practiceProblems.starterCode:
# String numbers that need conversion
num1_str = '15'
num2_str = '25'
# Convert to integers and calculate
practiceProblems.expectedOutput:
Sum: 40
Product: 375
Average: 20.0
practiceProblems.solution:
num1_str = '15'
num2_str = '25'

num1 = int(num1_str)
num2 = int(num2_str)

sum_result = num1 + num2
product = num1 * num2
average = sum_result / 2

print('Sum:', sum_result)
print('Product:', product)
print('Average:', average)

quiz.question: Which of these is a valid variable name in Python?
What data type is the value 3.14?
Which function tells you the data type of a variable?

title: Dictionaries and Key-Value Data
description: Master Python dictionaries for storing and accessing data with keys.

steps.title: Understanding Dictionaries
steps.content: Dictionaries are collections of key-value pairs, similar to real-world dictionaries where words (keys) have definitions (values). They're unordered, mutable, and extremely useful for representing structured data like records, configurations, and mappings.

steps.title: Creating and Accessing Dictionaries
steps.content: Different ways to create and work with dictionaries:
steps.code:
# Creating dictionaries
student = {
    'name': 'Alice',
    'age': 20,
    'grade': 'A',
    'enrolled': True
}

# Empty dictionary
empty_dict = {}

# Accessing values
print(student['name'])        # Alice
print(student.get('age'))     # 20
print(student.get('phone', 'Not provided'))  # Not provided

# Check if key exists
print('grade' in student)     # True

steps.title: Modifying Dictionaries
steps.content: Dictionaries are mutable - you can change them after creation:
steps.code:
# Starting dictionary
product = {
    'name': 'Laptop',
    'price': 999.99,
    'category': 'Electronics'
}

# Add new key-value pairs
product['brand'] = 'TechCorp'
product['in_stock'] = True

# Update existing values
product['price'] = 899.99

# Remove items
del product['category']  # Remove with del
removed_stock = product.pop('in_stock')  # Remove and return value

print(product)
print(f'Stock status was: {removed_stock}')

steps.title: Dictionary Methods and Iteration
steps.content: Useful methods for working with dictionaries:
steps.code:
# Sample data
inventory = {
    'apples': 50,
    'bananas': 30,
    'oranges': 25,
    'grapes': 40
}

# Get all keys, values, and items
print('Fruits:', list(inventory.keys()))
print('Quantities:', list(inventory.values()))
print('All items:', list(inventory.items()))

# Iterate through dictionary
for fruit, quantity in inventory.items():
    print(f'{fruit}: {quantity} units')

# Dictionary comprehension
low_stock = {fruit: qty for fruit, qty in inventory.items() if qty < 35}
print('Low stock:', low_stock)

practiceProblems.title: Student Record
practiceProblems.description: Create a dictionary to store student information and display it.
practiceProblems.starterCode:
# Create a student record
student_id = '12345'
name = 'John Doe'
age = 18
major = 'Computer Science'
practiceProblems.expectedOutput:
Student Record:
ID: 12345
Name: John Doe
Age: 18
Major: Computer Science
practiceProblems.solution:
student_id = '12345'
name = 'John Doe'
age = 18
major = 'Computer Science'

student = {
    'id': student_id,
    'name': name,
    'age': age,
    'major': major
}

print('Student Record:')
print(f'ID: {student["id"]}')
print(f'Name: {student["name"]}')
print(f'Age: {student["age"]}')
print(f'Major: {student["major"]}')

practiceProblems.title: Inventory Manager
practiceProblems.description: Create an inventory system that tracks products and their quantities.
practiceProblems.starterCode:
# Inventory management system
inventory = {
    'laptops': 15,
    'mice': 50,
    'keyboards': 23
}
# Add monitors: 8, update laptops to 12, remove mice
practiceProblems.expectedOutput:
Updated Inventory:
laptops: 12
keyboards: 23
monitors: 8
Removed mice: 50 units
practiceProblems.solution:
inventory = {
    'laptops': 15,
    'mice': 50,
    'keyboards': 23
}

# Add monitors
inventory['monitors'] = 8

# Update laptops
inventory['laptops'] = 12

# Remove mice
removed_mice = inventory.pop('mice')

print('Updated Inventory:')
for item, quantity in inventory.items():
    print(f'{item}: {quantity}')
print(f'Removed mice: {removed_mice} units')

title: Object-Oriented Programming Basics
description: Learn to create classes and objects to organize and structure your code.

steps.title: What is Object-Oriented Programming?
steps.content: Object-Oriented Programming (OOP) is a programming paradigm that organizes code around objects and classes. A class is a blueprint for creating objects, and objects are instances of classes. OOP helps create more maintainable, reusable, and organized code through encapsulation, inheritance, and polymorphism.

steps.title: Creating Classes and Objects
steps.content: Define classes with the 'class' keyword and create objects (instances):
steps.code:
# Define a simple class
class Person:
    def __init__(self, name, age):
        self.name = name  # Instance attribute
        self.age = age
    
    def introduce(self):  # Instance method
        return f'Hi, I am {self.name}, {self.age} years old'
    
    def have_birthday(self):
        self.age += 1
        return f'{self.name} is now {self.age} years old'

# Create objects (instances)
person1 = Person('Alice', 25)
person2 = Person('Bob', 30)

print(person1.introduce())
print(person2.have_birthday())

steps.title: Class Attributes and Methods
steps.content: Classes can have attributes and methods shared by all instances:
steps.code:
class BankAccount:
    # Class attribute (shared by all instances)
    bank_name = 'PyBank'
    total_accounts = 0
    
    def __init__(self, owner, balance=0):
        self.owner = owner  # Instance attribute
        self.balance = balance
        BankAccount.total_accounts += 1  # Update class attribute
        self.account_number = BankAccount.total_accounts
    
    def deposit(self, amount):
        if amount > 0:
            self.balance += amount
            return f'Deposited ${amount}. New balance: ${self.balance}'
        return 'Invalid deposit amount'
    
    def withdraw(self, amount):
        if 0 < amount <= self.balance:
            self.balance -= amount
            return f'Withdrew ${amount}. New balance: ${self.balance}'
        return 'Insufficient funds or invalid amount'
    
    @classmethod
    def get_total_accounts(cls):
        return f'Total accounts: {cls.total_accounts}'

# Create accounts
account1 = BankAccount('Alice', 1000)
account2 = BankAccount('Bob', 500)

print(account1.deposit(200))
print(BankAccount.get_total_accounts())

title: Loops and Iteration
description: Master for and while loops to repeat code efficiently and handle collections.

steps.title: Understanding Loops
steps.content: Loops allow you to repeat code multiple times without writing it repeatedly. Python has two main types: 'for' loops (when you know how many times to repeat or iterate over collections) and 'while' loops (when you repeat until a condition changes). Loops are essential for processing data, automating tasks, and creating interactive programs.

practiceProblems.expectedOutput: Sum of 1 to 10: 55

title: Functions and Code Organization
description: Create reusable code blocks with functions, parameters, and return values.

steps.title: Why Functions Matter
steps.content: Functions are the building blocks of organized, maintainable code. They allow you to break complex problems into smaller, manageable pieces, avoid code repetition, and create reusable components. Functions make your code more readable, testable, and easier to debug.

steps.title: Creating and Calling Functions
steps.content: Basic function syntax and usage:
steps.code:
# Simple function
def greet():
    print('Hello, World!')

# Function with parameters
def greet_person(name, age=25):
    return f'Hello {name}, you are {age} years old'

# Function with multiple return values
def calculate_stats(numbers):
    total = sum(numbers)
    average = total / len(numbers)
    return total, average

# Call functions
greet()
message = greet_person('Alice')
print(message)

total, avg = calculate_stats([1, 2, 3, 4, 5])
print(f'Total: {total}, Average: {avg}')

steps.title: Advanced Function Features
steps.content: Variable arguments, keyword arguments, and lambda functions:

practiceProblems.title: Temperature Converter
practiceProblems.description: Create functions to convert between Celsius and Fahrenheit.
practiceProblems.starterCode:
# Temperature conversion functions
def celsius_to_fahrenheit(celsius):
    # Your code here
    pass

def fahrenheit_to_celsius(fahrenheit):
    # Your code here
    pass

# Test
temp_c = 25
temp_f = 77
practiceProblems.solution:
def celsius_to_fahrenheit(celsius):
    return (celsius * 9/5) + 32

def fahrenheit_to_celsius(fahrenheit):
    return (fahrenheit - 32) * 5/9

temp_c = 25
temp_f = 77

print(f'{temp_c}°C = {celsius_to_fahrenheit(temp_c)}°F')
print(f'{temp_f}°F = {fahrenheit_to_celsius(temp_f)}°C')

title: File Input and Output
description: Learn to read from and write to files for data persistence and processing.

steps.title: Why File Handling Matters
steps.content: File handling allows your programs to persist data beyond program execution, process large datasets, create logs, read configuration files, and interact with external data sources. It's essential for building real-world applications that need to store and retrieve information.

steps.title: Reading and Writing Files
steps.content: Basic file operations using context managers:
steps.code:
# Writing to a file
with open('example.txt', 'w') as file:
    file.write('Hello, World!\n')
    file.write('This is a Python file handling example.\n')
    file.writelines(['Line 3\n', 'Line 4\n'])

# Reading from a file
with open('example.txt', 'r') as file:
    content = file.read()
    print('Full content:')
    print(content)

# Reading line by line
with open('example.txt', 'r') as file:
    print('Line by line:')
    for line_number, line in enumerate(file, 1):
        print(f'{line_number}: {line.strip()}')

steps.title: Working with CSV and JSON Files
steps.content: Handle structured data formats:
steps.code:
import json
import csv
from io import StringIO

# Working with JSON
data = {
    'students': [
        {'name': 'Alice', 'grade': 85},
        {'name': 'Bob', 'grade': 92}
    ]
}

# Write JSON
with open('students.json', 'w') as file:
    json.dump(data, file, indent=2)

# Read JSON
with open('students.json', 'r') as file:
    loaded_data = json.load(file)
    print('JSON data:', loaded_data)

# Working with CSV (simulated)
csv_content = 'name,age,city\nAlice,25,NYC\nBob,30,LA'
csv_file = StringIO(csv_content)

reader = csv.DictReader(csv_file)
print('CSV data:')
for row in reader:
    print(f'{row["name"]} is {row["age"]} years old from {row["city"]}')

practiceProblems.title: Simple Log Writer
practiceProblems.description: Create a function that writes log messages to a file with timestamps.
practiceProblems.starterCode:
# Log writing function
import datetime

def write_log(message, log_file='app.log'):
    # Your code here
    pass

# Test
write_log('Application started')
write_log('User logged in')
practiceProblems.expectedOutput:
Log written to app.log
Log written to app.log
practiceProblems.solution:
import datetime

def write_log(message, log_file='app.log'):
    timestamp = datetime.datetime.now().strftime('%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S')
    log_entry = f'{timestamp} - {message}\n'
    
    with open(log_file, 'a') as file:
        file.write(log_entry)
    
    return f'Log written to {log_file}'

print(write_log('Application started'))
print(write_log('User logged in'))

title: Exception Handling and Debugging
description: Learn to handle errors gracefully and debug your Python programs effectively.

steps.title: Understanding Exceptions
steps.content: Exceptions are events that occur during program execution that disrupt normal flow. Python uses try-except blocks to handle exceptions gracefully, preventing crashes and providing meaningful error messages to users. Good exception handling makes your programs robust and user-friendly.

title: Modules and Packages
description: Organize code with modules, import libraries, and create reusable packages.

steps.title: Understanding Modules
steps.content: Modules are Python files containing definitions and statements that can be imported and used in other programs. They help organize code, avoid naming conflicts, and promote code reuse. Python has a rich standard library of built-in modules, and you can also create your own modules.

steps.title: Importing and Using Modules
steps.content: Different ways to import and use modules:
steps.code:
# Standard library modules
import math
import datetime
import random
from collections import Counter, defaultdict
import os

# Using imported modules
print(f'Pi: {math.pi}')
print(f'Square root of 16: {math.sqrt(16)}')

# Current date and time
now = datetime.datetime.now()
print(f'Current time: {now.strftime("%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S")}')

# Random numbers
print(f'Random number: {random.randint(1, 100)}')
print(f'Random choice: {random.choice(["apple", "banana", "cherry"])}')

# Collections
words = ['apple', 'banana', 'apple', 'cherry', 'banana', 'apple']
word_count = Counter(words)
print(f'Word frequency: {word_count}')

# Environment and system
print(f'Current directory: {os.getcwd()}')
print(f'Environment PATH: {os.environ.get("PATH", "Not found")[:50]}...')

steps.title: Creating Custom Modules
steps.content: How to create and organize your own modules:

practiceProblems.title: Date and Time Utilities
practiceProblems.description: Use the datetime module to create date formatting functions.
practiceProblems.starterCode:
# Date and time utilities
import datetime

def format_date(date_obj):
    # Format as 'January 15, 2024'
    pass

def days_until_birthday(birthday_str):
    # Calculate days until next birthday
    # birthday_str format: 'MM-DD' (e.g., '03-15')
    pass

# Test
today = datetime.date.today()
birthday = '03-15'
practiceProblems.expectedOutput:
Today: January 15, 2024
Days until birthday: 59
practiceProblems.solution:
import datetime

def format_date(date_obj):
    return date_obj.strftime('%B %d, %Y')

def days_until_birthday(birthday_str):
    today = datetime.date.today()
    month, day = map(int, birthday_str.split('-'))
    
    # This year's birthday
    this_year_birthday = datetime.date(today.year, month, day)
    
    # If birthday has passed this year, calculate for next year
    if this_year_birthday < today:
        next_birthday = datetime.date(today.year + 1, month, day)
    else:
        next_birthday = this_year_birthday
    
    delta = next_birthday - today
    return delta.days

today = datetime.date.today()
birthday = '03-15'

print(f'Today: {format_date(today)}')
print(f'Days until birthday: {days_until_birthday(birthday)}')

quiz.question: How do you import only specific functions from a module?
What is the purpose of the __name__ == '__main__' check?
options: To check if the file is being run directly
